comment._content: H. Appenrodt (?), lunch, diners, soupers, comestibles, grill room, afternoon teas. In the bottom right, the word "anglais" can just be made out. Apparently they catered to British expats.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Appenrodt appears to have had a chain of cafes in London, according to books.google.com/books?id=SCQEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA166&l... the 1914 Gourmet's Guide to London.

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: "diners" & "soupers" are French words, meaning dinner and supper respectably (not surprisingly, since most of kitchen English is derived from French). I'm pretty sure that's Appenrodt, with the windowpane smashed near the hook of the R. Confirmed: CLAIMS BRITISH CITIZENSHIP.; Appenrodt, Whose Paris Restaurant Was Looted, Plans to Reopen. The New York Times, November 19, 1914.

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: trialsanderrors, and swanq:  Thank you for  uncovering more about this image. The NYT article confirms the name of the restaurant and gives the reason why it was looted in the early days of World War I.  The Gourmet's Guide to London also gives  more details about the history of the restaurant and its owner. We appreciate the good sources!
